awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ice sheet erosional interaction with hot geotherm in West Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
Sediment records off the coast of Marie Byrd Land (MBL), Antarctica suggest frequent and dramatic changes in the size of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) over short (tens of thousands of years) and long (millions of years) time frames in the past.  WAIS currently overrides much of MBL and covers the rugged and scoured bedrock landscape. The ice sheet carved narrow linear troughs that reach depths of two to three thousand meters below sea level as outlet glaciers flowed from the interior of the continent to the oceans. As a result, large volumes of fragmented continental bedrock were carried out to the seabed. The glaciers cut downward into a region of crystalline rocks (i.e. granite) whose temperature change as a function of rock depth happens to be significant. This strong geothermal gradient in the bedrock is favorable for determining when the bedrock experienced rapid exhumation or "uncovering". Analyzing the chemistry of minerals (zircon and apatite) within the eroded rocks will provide information about the rate and timing of the glacier removal of bedrock from the Antarctic continent. The research addresses the following questions: When did the land become high enough for a large ice sheet to form? What was the regional pre-glacial topography? Under what climate conditions, and at what point in the growth of an ice sheet, did glaciers begin to cut sharply into bedrock to form the narrow troughs that flow seaward? The research will lead to greater understanding of past Antarctic ice sheet fluctuations and identify precise timing of glacial incision. These results will refine ice sheet history and aid the international societal response to contemporary ice sheet change and its global consequences. The project will contribute to the training of two graduate and two undergraduate students in STEM.

The objective is to clarify the onset of WAIS glacier incision and assess the evolution of Cenozoic paleo-topography. Low-temperature (T) thermochronology and Pecube 3-D thermo-kinematic modeling will be applied to date and characterize episodes of glacial erosional incision. Single-grain double- and triple-dating of zircon and apatite will reveal the detailed crustal thermal evolution of the region enabling the research team to determine the comparative topographic influences on glaciation versus bedrock uplift induced by Eocene to present tectonism/magmatism. High-T mineral thermochronometers across Marie Byrd Land (MBL) record rapid extension-related cooling at ~100 Ma from temperatures of >800 degrees C to ≤ 300 degrees C. This signature forms a reference horizon, or paleogeotherm, through which the Cenozoic landscape history using low-T thermochronometers can be explored. MBL's elevated geothermal gradient, sustained during the Cenozoic, created favorable conditions for sensitive apatite and zircon low-T thermochronometers to record bedrock cooling related to glacial incision. Students will be trained to use state-of-the-art analytical facilities in Arizona and Minnesota, expanding the geo- and thermochronologic history of MBL from bedrock samples and offshore sedimentary deposits. The temperature and time data they acquire will provide constraints on paleotopography, isostasy, and the thermal evolution of MBL that will be modeled in 3D using Pecube model simulations. Within hot crust, less incision is required to expose bedrock containing the distinct thermochronometric profile; a prediction that will be tested with inverse Pecube 3-D models of the thermal field through which bedrock and detrital samples cooled. Using results from Pecube, the ICI-Hot team will examine time-varying topography formed in response to changes in erosion rates, topographic relief, geothermal gradient and/or flexural isostatic rigidity. These effects are manifestations of dynamic processes in the WAIS, including ice sheet loading, ice volume fluctuations, relative motion upon crustal faults, and magmatism-related elevation increase across the MBL dome. The project makes use of pre-existing sample collections housed at the US Polar Rock Repository, IODP's Gulf Coast Core Repository, and the Antarctic Marine Geology Research Facility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The up to 2 km thick West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS), in contrast to much of the ice sheet covering East Antarctica, rests on bedrock mostly below sea-level making it very vulnerable to melting and eventual collapse by warm sea-water infiltration in our currently warming climate. Complete melting of the WAIS would raise global sea-level up to 5 meters, and glaciers melting into the Amundsen Sea are currently Antarctica’s largest contributor to ongoing global sea-level rise. Computer models that simulate future atmosphere, ocean, and ice sheet behavior in response to increasing CO2 levels suggest WAIS melting will be a major player in global sea-level rise over the coming centuries. However, such modeling is still subject to considerable uncertainty, especially regarding the timing, rates, and magnitude of future WAIS retreat. A major part of this award has been to address such uncertainties by examining the geologic record of West Antarctica to understand more fully how the WAIS responded to past climate change. Gaining an accurate representation of the past provides a crucial basis for improving computer model replication of past conditions, allowing such models to predict more accurately the WAIS response to future climate change.

Because most of West Antarctica is buried by ice, we worked on bedrock material previously collected from rare, isolated rock outcrops in Marie Byrd Land (MBL), and bedrock detritus that was ground away by glaciers then transported and deposited offshore by melting icebergs in the form of mineral (sand) grains known as ice-rafted debris (IRD), and rock fragments known as dropstones. We obtained offshore material from archives of seafloor dredges and drill-cores collected during past ship expeditions offshore of West Antarctica. We applied two main analytical techniques: geochronology and thermochronology, the former dating of the time of rock formation, and the latter providing a temperature history that can be used to date the time and speed of rock erosion by glaciers draining the WAIS.

From 16 seabed dredges and drill-cores containing sediment dropped by melting icebergs in the last ~20,000 years offshore of MBL, we acquired almost 800 thermochronologic and over 1000 geochronologic IRD mineral grain dates and analyzed 18 dropstones using both methods. We also analyzed older sediment deposited over the last 6 million years acquired from deep-sea drill cores during 2019 International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) expedition to the Amundsen Sea, including thermochronologic and geochronologic data from almost 1000 mineral grains and 12 dropstones. Finally, we analyzed 36 onshore bedrock samples, including from newly discovered Sif Island, and 13 glacial erratics by both methods, including almost 900 individual thermochronologic and over 4800 individual geochronologic mineral grain dates.

Although collaborative parts of this award are ongoing at time of writing this report, preliminary outcomes are summarized below:

1) Clarifying the debated timing of when the WAIS first formed and started carving the topography of MBL: Preliminary thermochronologic data analysis from onshore bedrock and offshore dropstones indicates much of MBL has undergone very little erosion over the last 100 million years. However, some data suggests localized cooling (likely linked to carving by glaciers) starting in the last 20 million years, or possibly even more recently.

2) Understanding how MBL landscape has changed over time: Thermochronologic data from IRD offshore of central MBL show younger dates than other parts of MBL suggesting deep glacial valleys along this part of the coast were carved in the last 20 million years. However, geochronologic analysis also revealed many IRD mineral grains from young onshore volcanoes requiring ongoing careful evaluation of such data in terms of onshore landscape evolution.

3) Improving our knowledge of the bedrock geology beneath the WAIS: Geochronologic analysis of IRD and dropstones indicate much of the coast of MBL is dominated by granite-like rocks formed some 100 to 130 million years ago. We also discovered several 80 million years old sandstone dropstones, further clarifying links between subglacial MBL and similar-aged rocks found onshore and offshore of New Zealand.

4) Dating IRD and dropstones deposited during warmer climate periods 3 to 5 million years ago to infer past retreat of the WAIS: Initial findings indicate that IRD deposited during past warm periods show some differences from IRD deposited at times of fuller glaciation, supporting significant retreat of the WAIS when the global temperatures were only a few degrees warmer than today. Work is ongoing to use these data to assess more fully the extent of WAIS retreat during these times.

Broader impacts of this award include engaging numerous visiting undergraduate and graduate students to the University of Arizona with experience in the acquisition, interpretation, and presentation (at national and international conferences) of geochronologic and thermochronologic data The award fostered new international collaboration with the broader Antarctic geoscience community including the IODP, the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research, and the International Thwaites Glacier Collaboration.
